 \vspace*{2.0cm}
 \begin{center}
 {\Large \bf
 Massive Feynman diagrams and inverse binomial sums
 }
 \end{center}
 
\vspace{3mm}
 
 \begin{center}
 A.~I.~Davydychev$^{a,}$\footnote{
 Current address: Schlumberger, SPC, 110 Schlumberger Dr., MD-5,
 TX~77478, USA.
 Email address:
 davyd@thep.physik.uni-mainz.de}
 \quad  and \quad
 M.~Yu.~Kalmykov$^{b,}$\footnote{
Supported by DFG under Contract SFB/TR~9-03. 
On leave from BLTP, JINR, 141980 Dubna, Russia.
Email address: kalmykov@ifh.de}\\
 
\vspace{3mm}

$^{a}${\em
Institute for Nuclear Physics, 
Moscow State University, \\
 119992, Moscow, Russia}
\\
\vspace{.3cm}
$^{b}${\em
 DESY--Zeuthen,
Theory Group, Platanenallee 6, \\ D-15738 Zeuthen, Germany}
\\
\end{center}
  
 \hspace{3in}
 \begin{abstract}
 When calculating higher terms of the $\varepsilon$-expansion
 of massive Feynman diagrams, one needs to evaluate
 particular cases of multiple inverse binomial sums.
 These sums are related to the derivatives of certain
 hypergeometric functions with respect to their parameters.
 We explore this connection and
 analytically calculate a number of such infinite sums,
 for an arbitrary value of the argument which corresponds to
 an arbitrary value of the off-shell external momentum.
 In such a way, we find a number of new results for
 physically important two-loop two- and three-point
 Feynman diagrams. The results are presented in terms
 of generalized polylogarithmic functions.
\end{abstract}

\vspace{3mm}

%\noindent

\setcounter{footnote}{0}

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\section{Introduction}
\setcounter{equation}{0}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%

In many cases,
the results of analytical calculation of Feynman diagrams can be 
represented as combinations of hypergeometric functions. 
However, the problem of constructing the $\varepsilon$-expansion of
hypergeometric functions within dimensional regularization~\cite{dimreg} 
(where $n=4-2\varepsilon$ is the space-time dimension) is not completely solved.
Rather often,  
results for the terms of the $\varepsilon$-expansion can be expressed in terms of 
polylogarithms~\cite{Lewin} as well as 
Nielsen polylogarithms~\cite{Nielsen}. 
Recently it was demonstrated that new types of functions, 
harmonic polylogarithms~\cite{RV00} and 
multiple polylogarithms~\cite{GR2001}, appear in 
multiloop calculations. Furthermore, the nested sums~\cite{nested}
were proposed as a generalization of multiple polylogarithms, and 
the $\varepsilon$-expansion for a large class of hypergeometric function 
was constructed. 

In this paper we study the {\it multiple inverse binomial sums}
defined as\footnote{Some particular results for 
the {\it multiple binomial sums} are presented in \cite{poleII}. 
Those sums are defined similarly to Eq.~(\ref{binsum}),
but with $\left( 2j \atop j\right)$ in the numerator, rather
than in the denominator.}
\begin{equation}
\Sigma_{a_1,\ldots,a_p;
\; b_1,\ldots,b_q;c}^{\; i_1,\ldots,i_p; \;j_1,\ldots,j_q}(u)
\equiv
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j \atop j\right) } \frac{u^j}{j^c}
[S_{a_1}(j\!-\!1)]^{i_1}\ldots [S_{a_p}(j\!-\!1)]^{i_p}\;
[S_{b_1}(2j\!-\!1)]^{j_1}\ldots [S_{b_q}(2j\!-\!1)]^{j_q},
\label{binsum}
\end{equation}
where $S_a(j)\equiv\sum_{k=1}^j k^{-a}$ is the harmonic sum\footnote{
Through the rest of this paper, the notations $S_a$ and $\bar{S}_a$
will always mean $S_a(j-1)$ and $S_a(2j-1)$, respectively, 
even we do not mention this explicitly.} 
and $u$ is an arbitrary argument.
In what follows, we will also use
$z\equiv {\textstyle{\frac{1}{4}}}u$
as the argument of the occurring hypergeometric functions.
For sums of the type~(\ref{binsum}), the
{\em weight} ${\bf J}$
can be defined as 
${\bf J} = c + \sum_{k=1}^{p} a_k i_k + \sum_{k=1}^{q} b_k j_k$, 
whereas the {\em depth} can be associated with the sum 
$\sum_{k=1}^{p} i_k + \sum_{k=1}^{q} j_k$.

The sums~(\ref{binsum})
appear in the calculation of massive Feynman diagrams 
within several different approaches: for instance, as solutions of 
differential equations for Feynman amplitudes~\cite{dem}, or
through a na\"ive $\varepsilon$-expansion of hypergeometric functions 
within Mellin--Barnes technique~\cite{BD-TMF}.
Physical applications include the one-, two- and three-loop 
massive Feynman diagrams with two massive cuts 
\cite{FKV98,DD,FKV99,DK-bastei,DK01,oneloop}. 
The case $u=1$ corresponds to the single-scale propagator-type 
diagrams~\cite{single}. 
Although there are many publications 
concerning harmonic series~\cite{harmonic},
only a limited number of results are available for the inverse binomial sums. 
Some particular results 
for $u=1,2,3$ can be extracted from~\cite{KV00,DK01}.
The sums with $u=1,3$ are expressible in terms 
of an ``odd'' basis~\cite{odd}, whereas the case $u=2$
corresponds to an ``even'' basis~\cite{DK01,euler}\footnote{The connection 
between ``sixth root of unity''~\cite{B99}
and ``odd''/``even'' bases was discussed in~\cite{DK01,review}.}. 
However, only for special type of sums the analytical 
results are available~\cite{KV00,sums,BBK},
\begin{equation}
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j \atop j\right) } \frac{u^j}{j^c}   = 
 - \sum_{i=0}^{c-2} \frac{(-2)^i}{i! (c-2-i)!} 
( \ln u )^{c-2-i} {\mbox{Ls}}_{i+2}^{(1)}\left(\theta\right) \;,
\end{equation}
where
$c \geq 2$,
\begin{equation}
\label{def_theta}
\theta \equiv 2\arcsin\left({\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}}\sqrt{u}\right) 
= 2\arcsin\sqrt{z}\; , 
\end{equation}
%
\begin{equation}
\label{def_Ls}
{\mbox{Ls}}_{j}^{(k)}\left(\theta\right) =   - \int\limits_0^\theta {\rm d}\phi \;
   \phi^k \ln^{j-k-1} \left| 2\sin\frac{\phi}{2}\right| \, ,
\quad 
{\mbox{Ls}}_{j}\left(\theta\right) = {\mbox{Ls}}_{j}^{(0)}\left(\theta\right) \; 
\end{equation}
is the generalized log-sine function~\cite{Lewin}.
Some examples when such functions occur in the $\varepsilon$-expansion
of Feynman diagrams can be found in Refs.~\cite{Ls_ex,odd,D-ep}.
Usually, the occurring angles~(\ref{def_theta}),
possess certain geometrical meaning~\cite{DD}. 

The main aim of the present publication is the analytical 
calculation of inverse binomial sums~(\ref{binsum}),
including some relevant examples of physically important 
Feynman diagrams.

The paper is organized as follows. 
In Section~2, employing the connection with the $\varepsilon$-expansion
of hypergeometric functions,
we obtain analytical results for sums of the type~(\ref{binsum}),
valid for $u\leq 4$ ($z\leq 1$). Mainly the sums of
the {\em weights}~${\bf 3}$ and ${\bf 4}$ are considered.  
In Section~3 the analytical continuation 
to other values of $u$ is constructed. 
Section~4 contains some applications of our results related to 
the $\varepsilon$-expansion of Feynman diagrams, 
mainly two-loop master integrals. In Appendix~A we briefly summarize 
the relevant properties of the harmonic polylogarithms 
of complex arguments and related functions.
In Appendix~B we show how certain identities between hypergeometric
functions can be used to establish relations between the corresponding sums.
Appendix~C contains a realistic example of a physical application
of the considered integrals. 

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\section{Inverse binomial sums and hypergeometric functions}
\setcounter{equation}{0}

\subsection{The $\varepsilon$-expansion of the $_2F_1$ function}

Here, our analysis is based on comparing
two representations of hypergeometric function whose parameters
depend on $\varepsilon$. 
One of them is the series representation in terms of the harmonic sums,
whereas the second one is the exact result in terms of the
functions related to the polylogarithms. 

In particular, we consider the $_{2}F_1$ 
hypergeometric function of a special type,
\begin{equation}
_{2}F_1\left(\begin{array}{c|}
1+a_1\varepsilon, 1+a_2 \varepsilon\\
{\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} + b \varepsilon  \end{array} ~z \right)
= \sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \frac{u^j}{j!}\;
\frac{(1+a_1\varepsilon)_j (1+a_2\varepsilon)_j (2+b\varepsilon)_j}  
{(3+2b\varepsilon)_{2j}} \; ,
\end{equation}
where $u=4z$, $(\alpha)_j\equiv\Gamma(\alpha+j)/\Gamma(\alpha)$ is
the Pochhammer symbol,
and we have used the duplication formula
$(2\beta)_{2j}=4^j(\beta)_j(\beta+{\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}})_j$.
To perform the $\varepsilon$-expansion we use the well-known 
representation
\begin{equation}
(1+a\varepsilon)_j = j! \; \exp\left[ -\sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-a\varepsilon)^k}{k}
S_k(j) \right] \; ,
\label{pochhamer}
\end{equation}
which yields
\begin{eqnarray}
&& \hspace*{-15mm}
_{2}F_1\left(\begin{array}{c|}
1+a_1\varepsilon, 1+a_2 \varepsilon\\
{\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} + b \varepsilon  \end{array} ~z \right)
= \frac{2(1 + 2 b\varepsilon)}{u} 
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j \atop j\right) }  \frac{u^j}{j}  
\Biggl\{
1 
+ \varepsilon \left[ 
   (A_1+b)S_1 - 2 b \bar{S}_1
      \right] 
\nonumber \\ && 
+  \varepsilon^2 \Bigl[ 
2 b^2 \left( \bar{S}_2 + \bar{S}_1^2 \right) 
-  2 b (A_1+b) S_1 \bar{S}_1 
- {\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} (A_2+b^2) S_2
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} (A_1+b)^2 S_1^2
\Bigr]
\nonumber \\ && 
+ \varepsilon^3 \Bigl[ 
{\textstyle{\frac{1}{6}}} (A_1+b) ^3 S_1^3 
- b (A_1+b)^2 S_1^2 \bar{S}_1 
- {\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} (A_1+b)(A_2+b^2)S_1 S_2
\nonumber \\ && \hspace{10mm}
+ 2 b^2 (A_1+b) S_1 \left( \bar{S}_2 + \bar{S}_1^2 \right)
+ b (A_2+b^2) S_2 \bar{S}_1
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{6}}} (2 b^3 - A_1^3 + 3 A_1 A_2) S_3
\nonumber \\ && \hspace{10mm}
- {\textstyle{\frac{4}{3}}} b^3 
\left( 2 \bar{S}_3 + 3 \bar{S}_2 \bar{S}_1 + \bar{S}_1^3 \right)
\Bigr]
+ {\cal O} (\varepsilon^4)
\Biggr\} \; ,
\label{hyper:f21}
\end{eqnarray}
where $A_k \equiv a_1^k+a_2^k.$
Note that the coefficient of the $\varepsilon^3$ term can be represented as
\begin{eqnarray}
\label{combinations}
&& \hspace*{-7mm}
{\textstyle{\frac{1}{6}}}(A_1^3+b^3) C_0 
+2 b^2 (A_1+b) C_1
+4 b^3 C_2
+{\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} b (A_1-b) (A_1-2b) C_3
\nonumber \\ &&
+{\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} (A_1^2-A_2) (A_1+b) \left(S_1 S_2-S_3\right)
+{\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} b (A_1^2-A_2) \left(S_3-2 S_2 \bar{S}_1\right) \; ,
\end{eqnarray}
where we have introduced the following combinations of 
harmonic sums:
\begin{eqnarray}
\label{combinations2}
C_0&=& S_1^3-3S_1S_2+2S_3\; ,
\nonumber \\
C_1&=& 
S_1^3-S_1 S_2+S_1 (\bar{S}_1^2+\bar{S}_2)
-{\textstyle{\frac{5}{2}}} S_1^2 \bar{S}_1+{\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} S_2 \bar{S}_1 \; ,
\nonumber \\
C_2&=&  {\textstyle{\frac{3}{4}}}S_1 S_2 - {\textstyle{\frac{3}{4}}}S_1^3
+{\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}}S_1^2\bar{S}_1 - S_2\bar{S}_1 
-{\textstyle{\frac{1}{3}}} \left( 2\bar{S}_3 + 3 \bar{S}_1\bar{S}_2
+\bar{S}_1^3\right) \; ,
\nonumber \\
C_3&=& S_1^3-2 S_1^2 \bar{S}_1 - S_1 S_2 + 2 S_2 \bar{S}_1 \; .
\end{eqnarray}
To completely define the $\varepsilon^3$ order of the expansion
of $_2F_1$, we need results for six combinations
of sums, according to the number of independent
combinations of the parameters $A_i$ and $b$.

Let us first consider the case $0\leq u \leq 4 $ ($0\leq z\leq 1$).
In this region  the following parametrization 
can be used:  
$u = 4 \sin^2{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}$ ($z= \sin^2{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}$),
where $0 \leq \theta \leq \pi.$
In the rest of this paper, we will use the short-hand notation 
\begin{equation}
L_\theta \equiv
\ln \left( 2 \cos {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right) \; , \qquad  
l_\theta \equiv
\ln \left( 2 \sin {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right) \; .
\end{equation}

For a few special cases, the $\varepsilon$-expansion of the 
$_2F_1$ functions is known. 
First of all, the following relation holds~\cite{PBM3}:
\begin{equation}
{}_{2}F_1 \left(\begin{array}{c|} \!\! 1\!+\!\varepsilon, 1 \!-\! \varepsilon\! \\
\frac{3}{2} \end{array} ~\sin^2 {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right)\! =
\frac{\sin \left( \varepsilon \theta \right)}{\varepsilon \sin(\theta)} \; .
\label{basis_I}
\end{equation}
Its expansion contains only the even powers of~$\varepsilon$.
Using it, it is easy to get 
\begin{eqnarray}
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} \frac{u^j}{j} S_2 
&=&  {\textstyle{\frac{1}{6}}} \theta^3 
\tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \; ,
\label{S2}
\\
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} 
\frac{u^j}{j} \left( S_2^2 - S_4 \right)
&=&  {\textstyle{\frac{1}{60}}} \theta^5 
\tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \; ,
\label{S4}
\end{eqnarray}
etc. Then, there are some cases~\cite{D-ep,DK01} when 
an arbitrary term of the $\varepsilon$-expansion can be calculated
in terms of log-sine functions, 
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\begin{eqnarray}
_2F_1 \left(\begin{array}{c|} 1, 1+\varepsilon  \\
{\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} \end{array} ~\sin^2 {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right)
&=& \frac{\left( 2 \cos {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right)^{-2\varepsilon}}{\sin \theta} 
\sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \frac{(2\varepsilon)^j}{j!}
\left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{j+1}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{j+1}\left(\pi\right) \right] \; ,
\label{basis_II}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\\
_2F_1 \left(\begin{array}{c|} 1, 1+\varepsilon  \\
{\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}}+\varepsilon \end{array} ~\sin^2 {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right)
 &=& -\frac{2(1+2\varepsilon)}{\sin\theta (\sin{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}})^{2\varepsilon}}
 \sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \frac{(2\varepsilon)^j}{j!} {\mbox{Ls}}_{j+1}\left(\theta\right) \; ,
\\
_2F_1 \left(\begin{array}{c|} 1, 1+\varepsilon  \\
{\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}}+{\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}}\varepsilon \end{array} ~\sin^2 {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right)
 &=& -\frac{1+\varepsilon}{(2\sin\theta)^{1+\varepsilon}}
 \sum_{j=0}^{\infty} \frac{\varepsilon^j}{j!} {\mbox{Ls}}_{j+1}\left(2\theta\right) \; .
\end{eqnarray}
Moreover, for a more general case an integral representation 
can be obtained~\cite{PBM3,DK01},
\begin{equation}
{}_{2}F_1 \left(\begin{array}{c|} 1, 1 \!+\! a \varepsilon \\
\frac{3}{2}+b \varepsilon \end{array} ~\sin^2 {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right) =
\frac{(1\!+\! 2 b \varepsilon)\left( 2 \cos {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right)^{2b\varepsilon-2a\varepsilon}}
{ \sin \theta \left( 2 \sin {\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}} \right)^{2b\varepsilon}}
\int\limits_0^\theta {\rm d}\phi
\left(2 \sin {\textstyle{\frac{\phi}{2}}} \right)^{2b\varepsilon} 
\left(2 \cos {\textstyle{\frac{\phi}{2}}} \right)^{2a\varepsilon-2b\varepsilon} . 
\label{basis_III}
\end{equation}
Any order of the $\varepsilon$-expansion of Eq.~(\ref{basis_III})
can be expressed in terms of 
the generalized ``log-sine-cosine'' function ${\mbox{Lsc}}_{i,j\!}\left(\theta\right)$
whose properties are listed in Appendix~B of Ref.~\cite{DK01},
\begin{equation}
\label{Lsc}
{\mbox{Lsc}}_{i,j\!}\left(\theta\right)=-\int\limits_0^{\theta}
{\rm d}\phi\; \ln^{i-1}\Bigl|2\sin{\textstyle{\frac{\phi}{2}}}\Bigr| \;
\ln^{j-1}\Bigl|2\cos{\textstyle{\frac{\phi}{2}}}\Bigr| \; .
\end{equation}
Up to the level $i+j=5$, only one independent function
appears, ${\mbox{Lsc}}_{2,3\!}\left(\theta\right)$, that cannot be expressed
in terms of ordinary log-sine integrals. 
Note that ${\mbox{Lsc}}_{2,3\!}\left(\pi-\theta\right)$ can be reduced 
to ${\mbox{Lsc}}_{2,3\!}\left(\theta\right)$ by using 
Eq.~(A.27) of Ref.~\cite{DK01}.

Using Eqs.~(\ref{basis_II})--(\ref{basis_III}), we obtain 
the following results for the weight-{\bf 2} and weight-{\bf 3}
sums, in addition to Eq.~(\ref{S2}): 
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\begin{eqnarray}
&& 
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} \frac{u^j}{j} S_1 
=  2 \tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}
\Bigl[{\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi- \theta\right)  - \theta L_\theta \Bigr] \;,
\label{S1a}
\\ && 
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} \frac{u^j}{j} \bar{S}_1
=  
\tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}
\Bigl[
2 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi- \theta\right)
+  {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\theta\right)
+  \theta l_\theta
- 2 \theta L_\theta
\Bigr] \; ,
\label{S1bar}
\\ && 
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)}  \frac{u^j}{j} S_1^2 
=  4 \tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}
\Bigl[
{\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right)
- 2 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) L_\theta
+ \theta L^2_\theta
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{24}}} \theta^3 
\Bigr] \;, 
\hspace*{7mm}
\label{S1S1}
\\ && 
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)}
\frac{u^j}{j} S_1 \bar{S}_1
=
\tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}  
\Bigl\{
  5  \left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \right]
-    {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\theta\right)
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(2\theta\right)
\nonumber \\ && \hspace*{5mm}
+ 2  {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) l_\theta
- 8  {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) L_\theta
- 2 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\theta\right) L_\theta
- 2 \theta l_\theta  L_\theta 
+ 4 \theta  L_\theta^2 
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{12}}} \theta^3
\Bigr\} \; ,
\label{S1S1bar}
\\ && 
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)}
\frac{u^j}{j} 
\left( \bar{S}_2 + \bar{S}_1^2 \right) 
=
\tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}  
\Bigl\{
  6  \left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \right]
- 3  {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\theta\right)
\nonumber \\ && \hspace*{5mm}
+ 4  {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) l_\theta
- 8  {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) L_\theta
+ 2  {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\theta\right) l_\theta
+ {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(2\theta\right)
- 4 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\theta\right) L_\theta
\nonumber \\ && \hspace*{5mm}
+ \theta l^2_\theta
- 4 \theta  L_\theta l_\theta
+ 4 \theta  L^2_\theta 
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{12}}} \theta^3
\Bigr\} \; ,
\label{S2S1bar}
\end{eqnarray}
where ${\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right)=-{\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}}\pi\zeta_2$.
In fact, all ${\mbox{Ls}}_{j}\left(\pi\right)$ are expressible 
in terms of the $\zeta$-function~\cite{Lewin}.

For the weight {\bf 4}, the results for some combinations
of sums involved in~(\ref{combinations}) can also be expressed
in terms of log-sine functions, using 
Eqs.~(\ref{basis_II})--(\ref{basis_III}),
\begin{eqnarray}
&& \hspace*{-10mm} 
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} \frac{u^j}{j} C_0
= 
8 \tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}
\Bigl\{
{\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(\pi-\theta\right) \!-\! {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(\pi\right) 
\nonumber \\ && \hspace{15mm} 
\!-\! 3 \Bigl[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi \!-\! \theta\right) \!-\! {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \Bigr] L_\theta
\!+\! 3 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi \!-\! \theta\right) L^2_\theta
\!-\! \theta L^3_\theta
\Bigr\} \; ,
\label{combination:1}
\\ && \hspace*{-10mm}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} \frac{u^j}{j} C_1 
= 
\tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}  
\Bigl\{
{\textstyle{\frac{2}{3}}} {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(\theta\right)
- {\textstyle{\frac{1}{3}}} {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left( 2\theta\right)
- {\textstyle{\frac{14}{3}}} \left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left( \pi - \theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left( \pi\right) \right]
\nonumber \\ && 
+ 14 \left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left( \pi - \theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \right] L_\theta
- 2 {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\theta\right) l_\theta
+ {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(2 \theta\right) \left[ L_\theta + l_\theta \right]
- 14 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) L_\theta^2
\nonumber \\ && 
+ 2 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) l_\theta^2
- 2 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(2 \theta\right) L_\theta l_\theta   
- {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(2 \theta\right) L_\theta^2
- 2 \theta L_\theta l_\theta^2
- 2 \theta L_\theta^2 l_\theta
+ 4 \theta L_\theta^3 
\Bigr\} \;, 
\\ && \hspace*{-10mm}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} \frac{u^j}{j} C_2 
= 
\tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}  
\Bigl\{
{\textstyle{\frac{1}{3}}} {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(2 \theta\right)
- {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(\theta\right)
+ 4 \left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(\pi - \theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(\pi\right)  \right] 
- {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(2 \theta\right)\left( l_\theta + L_\theta  \right) 
\nonumber \\ &&
- 12 \left[{\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \right] L_\theta
+ 3 {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\theta\right) l_\theta 
+ 12 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) L_\theta^2  
- 3 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) l_\theta^2
\nonumber \\ &&
- {\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(2\theta\right) l_\theta^2 
+ {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(2\theta\right) L_\theta^2 
+ 2 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(2\theta\right) l_\theta L_\theta 
+ 2 \theta  l_\theta^2 L_\theta
+ 2 \theta  l_\theta L_\theta^2
- {\textstyle{\frac{1}{3}}} \theta  l_\theta^3
- {\textstyle{\frac{10}{3}}} \theta L_\theta^3 
\Bigr\} \; ,
\end{eqnarray}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
where ${\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(\pi\right)={\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}}\pi\zeta_3$
and the combination of the harmonic sums $C_j$ are defined in (\ref{combinations2}).
Finally, using (\ref{basis_III}) the result for the sum involving $C_3$ 
can be expressed in terms of the ${\mbox{Lsc}}$-function (\ref{Lsc}),
\begin{eqnarray}
\label{last4}
&& \hspace*{-10mm}
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} \frac{u^j}{j} C_3
= 
- 4\tan{\textstyle{\frac{\theta}{2}}}  
\Bigl\{ 
  2 {\mbox{Lsc}}_{2,3\!}\left(\theta\right)
+ 2  \left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{4}\left(\pi\right) \right]
\nonumber \\ && 
+ 2 \left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \right] l_\theta
- 8 \left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \right] L_\theta
- {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(2 \theta\right) L_\theta 
+ 2 {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\theta\right) L_\theta 
\nonumber \\ && 
+ 8 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) L_\theta^2 
- 4 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) L_\theta  l_\theta   
+ {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(2 \theta\right) L_\theta^2
- 2 \theta  L_\theta^3
+ 2 \theta   L_\theta^2 l_\theta
\Bigr\}  \; .
\end{eqnarray}
Some of the results (\ref{S1a})--(\ref{last4}) can be written 
in a slightly different form by means of relations~\cite{Lewin}
$$
{\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\theta\right) = {\mbox{Cl}}_{2}\left(\theta\right) \; , \quad 
{\mbox{Cl}}_{2n}\left(\pi+\theta\right) = - {\mbox{Cl}}_{2n}\left(\pi-\theta\right) \; , \quad
{\mbox{Cl}}_{2n+1}\left(\pi+\theta\right) = {\mbox{Cl}}_{2n+1}\left(\pi-\theta\right) \; . 
$$

However, in this way one cannot obtain
results for the two remaining combinations 
in~(\ref{combinations}),
involving $A_1^2-A_2=2a_1a_2$,
since in Eq.~(\ref{basis_III})
we always have $a_1a_2=0$. An interesting relation
between these two functions is obtained in Appendix~B. 
It should also be noted that for higher hypergeometric
functions other combinations of sums may arise
at this level (see below).

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\subsection{Expansion of higher functions}

Let us consider 
the hypergeometric function of the following type:
\begin{equation}
\hspace*{-3mm}
_{P+1}F_P\left(\begin{array}{c|}
{\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} + b_1 \varepsilon,\ldots, {\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} + b_{J-1} \varepsilon, \; 
1+a_1\varepsilon, \ldots, 1+a_K \varepsilon, \; 2+d_1 \varepsilon \ldots, 2+d_L \varepsilon \\
{\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} + f_1 \varepsilon, \ldots, {\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} + f_J \varepsilon, \; 
1+e_1\varepsilon, \ldots, 1+e_{R}\varepsilon, \; 
2+c_1\varepsilon, \ldots, 2+c_{K+L-R-2} \varepsilon
\end{array} ~z \right),
\label{PFQ}
\end{equation}
where $P=K+L+J-2$.
Using the representation (\ref{pochhamer})
its $\varepsilon$-expansion can be reduced to inverse binomial sums~(\ref{binsum}).
The original hypergeometric function (\ref{PFQ}) can be written as
(see details in Appendix~B of Ref.~\cite{DK01})
\begin{eqnarray}
&& \hspace*{-10mm}
_{P+1}F_P\left(\begin{array}{c|}
\{ {\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} +b_i\varepsilon\}^{J-1}, \; 
\{ 1+a_i\varepsilon\}^K, \; \{ 2+d_i\varepsilon\}^L  \\
\{ {\textstyle{\frac{3}{2}}} + f_i\varepsilon\}^J, \; 
\{ 1+e_i\varepsilon \}^R,
\{ 2+c_i\varepsilon \}^{K+L-R-2} 
\end{array} ~z \right)
\nonumber \\ && \hspace*{20mm}
= \frac{2}{u}
\frac{
\Pi_{s=1}^{K+L-R-2} (1+c_s\varepsilon)  
\Pi_{k=1}^{J} (1+ 2 f_k\varepsilon)}
{\Pi_{i=1}^{L} (1+d_i\varepsilon)
\Pi_{r=1}^{J-1} (1 + 2 b_r\varepsilon)}
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j \atop j \right) }  
\frac{u^j}{j^{K-R-1}}  
\Delta \;, 
\nonumber 
\end{eqnarray}
where $u=4z$,  
\begin{eqnarray}
\Delta &=& 
\exp \left[ \sum_{k=1}^{\infty} \frac{(-\varepsilon)^k}{k}  
\left( S_k T_k + 2^k U_k \bar{S}_k + W_k j^{-k} \right) 
\right]
\nonumber \\
&=&  
1 
- \varepsilon \left( 
   T_1 S_1 
+ W_1 j^{-1} 
+ 2 U_1 \bar{S}_1
\right)
+  \varepsilon^2 \Bigl[ 
{\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} j^{-2}\left( W_2 + W_1^2 \right) 
+ W_1 j^{-1} 
 \left( T_1 S_1 
+ 2 U_1 \bar{S}_1  \right)
\nonumber \\ &&
+  2 T_1 U_1 S_1 \bar{S}_1  
+ 2 U_2 \bar{S}_2 
+ 2 U_1^2 \bar{S}_1^2 
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} T_2  S_2 
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} T_1^2 S_1^2
\Bigr]
+ {\cal O}(\varepsilon^3)\; , 
\label{expansion}
\end{eqnarray}
and we introduced the constants 
\begin{eqnarray*}
&& \hspace*{-8mm}
A_k \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{K} a_i^k, \quad 
B_k \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{J-1} b_i^k, \quad 
C_k \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{K+L-R-2} c_i^k, \quad 
D_k \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{L} d_i^k, \quad 
E_k \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{R} e_i^k, \quad
F_k \equiv \sum_{i=1}^{J} f_i^k, 
\nonumber \\
&& \hspace*{-8mm}
T_k \equiv B_k + C_k + E_k - A_k - D_k - F_k, \quad
U_k \equiv F_k - B_k, \quad
W_k \equiv C_k - D_k. 
\end{eqnarray*}
Some results for separate terms 
of expansion~(\ref{expansion}) are collected in Section~2.1. 

%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
For the sums of the type~(\ref{binsum}) with an arbitrary integer power 
$c\geq 2$  and  $0 \leq u \leq 4$, the following one-fold integral 
representation \cite{BBK} is useful:
\begin{eqnarray}
\sum_{j=1}^\infty  \frac{u^j}{j^c} \frac{f(j)}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} =
\frac{1}{(c-2)!} \int\limits_0^{\theta}
{\rm d}\phi \frac{\cos {\textstyle{\frac{\phi}{2}}}}{\sin{\textstyle{\frac{\phi}{2}}}}
\Bigl[\ln{u} - 2\ln \left(2 \sin {\textstyle{\frac{\phi}{2}}} \right)\Bigr]^{c-2} 
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{\left( 4 \sin^2{\textstyle{\frac{\phi}{2}}} \right)^{j}}{j} 
\frac{f(j)}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)}  \; ,
\label{higher_c}
\end{eqnarray}
where $f(j)$ stands for an arbitrary combination of the harmonic sums.
In this manner, the original sum of the type~(\ref{binsum}) 
with an arbitrary positive integer parameter $c\geq 2$ is reduced
to a one-fold integral representation containing
a sum with $c=1$ in the integrand. 
Using the representation~(\ref{higher_c}) we can generalize our 
results~(\ref{S2}), (\ref{S4}), (\ref{S1a})--(\ref{last4})
to the case of an arbitrary integer $c>1$.
However, only for special types of sums these results are 
expressible in terms of generalized log-sine functions~(\ref{def_Ls}):
\begin{eqnarray}
&& \hspace*{-7mm}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\sum_{j=1}^\infty  \frac{u^j}{j^c} \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} S_2 =
- {\textstyle{\frac{1}{6}}} \sum_{i=0}^{c-2} \frac{(-2)^i}{i!(c-2-i)!} 
\left(\ln u \right)^{c-2-i} {\mbox{Ls}}_{i+4}^{(3)}\left(\theta\right) \;, 
\label{S2G}
\\ && \hspace*{-7mm}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\sum_{j=1}^\infty  \frac{u^j}{j^c} \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)}
\left( S_2^2-S_4 \right) =
- {\textstyle{\frac{1}{60}}} \sum_{i=0}^{c-2} \frac{(-2)^i}{i!(c-2-i)!} 
\left(\ln u \right)^{c-2-i} {\mbox{Ls}}_{i+6}^{(5)}\left(\theta\right) \;, 
\label{S4G}
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\end{eqnarray}
where $c \geq 2$, $0 \leq u \leq 4$, and the angle $\theta$ is
defined in Eq.~(\ref{def_theta}). 

Further results can be extracted 
from integral representation~(\ref{higher_c}) by using 
the integration rules for Clausen's function~\cite{Lewin} and 
the following relation:
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\[
k \int\limits_0^\theta {\rm d}\phi\;
{\phi}^{k-1} {\mbox{Ls}}_{j}^{(i)}\left(m \phi\right)
=  \theta^k {\mbox{Ls}}_{j}^{(i)}\left(m\theta\right) - \frac{1}{m^k} {\mbox{Ls}}_{j+k}^{(i+k)}\left(m \theta\right)
\; . 
\]
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
In this way, we obtain 
\begin{eqnarray}
\label{S1c2}
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j \atop j\right) } 
\frac{u^j}{j^2} S_1   &=&  
  4 {\mbox{Cl}}_{3}\left(\pi - \theta\right) - 2 \theta {\mbox{Cl}}_{2}\left(\pi - \theta\right) + 3 \zeta_3 , 
\\ 
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j \atop j \right) } 
\frac{u^j}{j^2} \bar{S}_1
 &=&  -2 {\mbox{Cl}}_{3}\left(\theta\right) + 4  {\mbox{Cl}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right)
- 2 \theta {\mbox{Cl}}_{2}\left(\pi- \theta\right)
-   \theta {\mbox{Cl}}_{2}\left(\theta\right)
+ 5 \zeta_3 \; , \hspace*{10mm}
\\ 
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j\atop j\right)} 
\frac{u^j}{j^2} S_1^2 
&=&  
4 \theta \left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \right]
-  4\left[ {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) \right]^2
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{24}}} \theta^4 \; ,
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\\  
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j \atop j\right) } 
      \frac{u^j}{j^2} S_1 \bar{S}_1
&=& 
 5 \theta \left[{\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \right]
- \theta {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\theta\right) 
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{2}}} \theta {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(2 \theta\right)
\nonumber \\ && 
- 4 \left[{\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) \right]^2
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{48}}} \theta^4 
- 2 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right)  {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\theta\right) \; , 
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%%
\\  
\sum_{j=1}^\infty \frac{1}{\left( 2j \atop j\right) } 
\frac{u^j}{j^2} 
\left( \bar{S}_1^2 + \bar{S}_2 \right)
&=& 
  6 \theta \left[{\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi-\theta\right) - {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\pi\right) \right]
- 3 \theta {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(\theta\right)
+  \theta {\mbox{Ls}}_{3}\left(2 \theta\right)
\nonumber \\ &&
- 4 \left[{\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) \right]^2
- \left[{\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\theta\right) \right]^2
+ {\textstyle{\frac{1}{48}}} \theta^4
- 4 {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right)  {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\theta\right) \; .
\label{S2bar_2}
\end{eqnarray}

However, other sums are not expressible in terms of 
the generalized log-sine functions.
One needs to introduce a new function\footnote{Alternatively,
instead of $\Phi(\theta)$ one may introduce the generalized
Glashier function ${\mbox{Gl}}_{4}\left(\theta;1\right)$, see Eq.~(\ref{Gl4(theta,1)}) 
in Appendix~A.},
\begin{equation}
\label{def_Phi}
\Phi(\theta) \equiv
\int\limits_0^\theta {\rm d}\phi\; 
{\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\phi\right) \ln \left(2 \cos {\textstyle{\frac{\phi}{2}}} \right) \; , 
\end{equation}
which obeys the following symmetry property:
\begin{equation}
\label{sym_Phi}
\Phi(\theta) + \Phi(\pi-\theta) 
= \Phi(\pi) + {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\pi-\theta\right) {\mbox{Ls}}_{2}\left(\theta\right) \;, 
\end{equation}
where 
\begin{eqnarray}
\hspace{-10mm}
\Phi(\pi) & = &  
{\textstyle{\frac{1}{6}}} \ln^4 2 - \zeta_2 \ln^2 2 + {\textstyle{\frac{7}{2}}} \zeta_3 \ln 2 
- {\textstyle{\frac{53}{16}}} \zeta_4 + 4 {\mbox{Li}}_{4}\left(
